Sequence Information.Peptide Name: DFT561 (Synthetic AMPs, DFT503 variant, Leu-rich; XXA, UCLL1c)

Literature.Author: Mishra B, Lakshmaiah Narayana J, Lushnikova T, Wang X, Wang G. 2019
Literature.Reference: Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A. 2019 Jul 2;116(27):13517-13522. doi: 10.1073/pnas.1821410116.PubMed
Literature.Title: Low cationicity is important for systemic in vivo efficacy of database-derived peptides against drug-resistant Gram-positive pathogens

Sequence Information.Comments: Sequence analysis: APD analysis reveals that this sequence is poorly similar (92.31%) toDFT503. L: 62%.Chemical modification:  C-terminal amidation.Activity: Active against S. aureus USA300 or M838-17 (MIC 1.56-3.1 uM), E. faecium V286-17  (MIC 3.1-6.25 uM) anti-VRE, P-aeruginosa PAO1 (MIC > 25 uM), E-coli ATCC 25922 (MIC> 25 uM), and K-pneumonia ATCC13883 (MIC > 25 uM).Toxicity:  human RBC HC50 >300 uM, much less hemo.lytic.MOA:bacteria:S. aureus: the peptide acted on bacterial membranes: permeabilization and depolarization.Structure:  NMR studies revealed helical structure bound to SDS micelles.Resistance development:no:bacteria:S. aureus USA300: S. aureus USA300 did not develop resistance to DFT561d (made of D-amino acids) in a multiple passage experiment after 14 passages while Nafcillin did.Animal model:mouse: DFT561 and DFT561d at 5 mg/kg showed similar systemic efficacy in neutropenic mice infected with MRSA (i.p./i.p.).Updated 8/2024
